item.title: America Pushes Allies to Fight Huawei in New Arms Race With China
item.media:description: Huawei’s offices in Warsaw. Polish officials recently came under pressure from the United States to bar Huawei from building its 5G communications network.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: With 5G networks about to remake the internet, the Trump administration fears decisions made in the next six months on China’s role will resonate for decades.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, JULIAN E. BARNES, RAYMOND ZHONG and MARC SANTORA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Bruised Trump Faces Uncertain 2020 Prospects. His Team Fears a Primary Fight.
item.media:description: President Trump at a campaign rally in Belgrade, Mont., in November. He captured the presidency with a largely improvisational candidacy, guided by his own instincts for personal combat and cultural division.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: With his approval rating sinking, and foes within the party wooing potential Republican challengers, aides to the president are working to shore up his support.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS, JONATHAN MARTIN and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: With Deadline Looming, Border Security Talks Face Hurdles in Congress
item.media:description: A Border Patrol agent near the southern border in Brownsville, Tex. President Trump is desperate to fulfill his 2016 campaign pledge for a “big, beautiful wall” along the border.
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.description: The reopening of the federal government kicked of three weeks of negotiations over border security. But there are obstacles ahead, including a divided Congress and an unpredictable president.
item.dc:creator: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
item.category: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

item.title: On Washington: With Pain Still Fresh, Lawmakers Make Push to Outlaw Shutdowns
item.media:description: Reporters followed Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, on Thursday after two measures to reopen the government failed in the Senate.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The toll of the latest impasse has prompted members of both parties to push for legislation that would ensure that the government wouldn’t be closed again as part of a budget negotiation.
item.dc:creator: CARL HULSE

item.title: U.S. and Taliban Edge Toward Deal to End America’s Longest War
item.media:description: American soldiers in a village about 90 miles northeast of Kandahar, Afghanistan, in 2006.
item.description: Six days of peace talks that wrapped up Saturday were the most serious negotiations yet to make way for an American troop withdrawal and an end to the 17-year war.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Quiet ‘Hero’ Marks 30 Years Restoring Limbs, and Dignity, in War
item.media:description: Alberto Cairo in 2014. “I hope to stay 30 more years,” he said.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: An Italian physiotherapist, Alberto Cairo, has spent three decades in Afghanistan leading centers that have treated tens of thousands of disabled people.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: These Patients Had Sickle-Cell Disease. Experimental Therapies Might Have Cured Them.
item.media:description: Brandon Williams received gene therapy to replace sickle cells with healthy hemoglobin. His sister, Britney, died of complications of sickle-cell disease. He has a tattoo of her name on his right arm.
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.description: Success against sickle-cell would be “the first genetic cure of a common genetic disease” and could free tens of thousands of Americans from agonizing pain.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Novak Djokovic Defeats Rafael Nadal for His 7th Australian Open Title
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic has won three Grand Slam tournaments in a row and has 15 major titles over all.
item.description: Djokovic, 31, whose career was wobbling a year ago, has won three straight Grand Slam championships, giving him 15 altogether.
item.dc:creator: KURT STREETER

item.title: Second Slam Title Signals Naomi Osaka Has the Power to Rule Tennis
item.media:description: Naomi Osaka won her second consecutive Grand Slam title on Saturday. She defeated Serena Williams at the United States Open in September.
item.description: Osaka, 21, has now won two straight Grand Slam titles and moved to the top of the world rankings.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: Rustic shelters called bothies. The laundry specialist to the stars. The $238 million penthouse. A raucous English family, and more.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN

item.title: Government Shutdown, Roger Stone, Novak Djokovic: Your Weekend Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY CALLOWAY-BLATCH and LANCE BOOTH

item.title: A Frat Boy and a Gentleman
item.description: One researcher found that fraternities were embracing “a more inclusive form of masculinity,” based on equality for gay men, respect for women, racial parity and emotional intimacy.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ROBBINS

item.title: Saving NATO
item.media:description: President Trump with Mike Pompeo and John Bolton at a NATO summit in 2018.
item.description: The House voted overwhelmingly to block President Trump’s threat to quit the Atlantic alliance. The Senate should promptly follow suit.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Stone-Cold Loser
item.media:description: Roger Stone posed for a portrait in his Upper East Side apartment in 2015.
item.media:credit: Jesse Dittmar for The New York Times
item.description: Will the dawn raid on the Prince of Darkness shine a light on the Trump campaign’s original sin?
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: She Wanted to Drive, So Saudi Arabia’s Ruler Imprisoned and Tortured Her
item.media:description: Loujain al-Hathloul recorded a video in 2014 showing her driving in the United Arab Emirates toward the border with Saudi Arabia.
item.description: The U.S. should pressure Saudis to respect the human rights of outspoken women.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Case Against Impeachment
item.media:description: President Trump walks into the Oval Office after announcing a temporary end to the government shutdown on Friday.
item.description: Three (provisional) reasons not to put the president on trial.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: The Loneliness of the Moderate Democrat
item.media:description: Gov. Gina Raimondo of Rhode Island. She argues that Democrats are too unfriendly to business.
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.description: ‘It takes a lot of spine to be a centrist in America today.’
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Mueller’s Real Target in the Roger Stone Indictment
item.media:description: Roger Stone in Washington in December 2018.
item.description: It was probably not Stone himself, but rather his electronic devices.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN SANCHEZ
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: The Real Wall Isn’t at the Border
item.media:description: An aerial view of the fence between California and Tijuana, Mexico.
item.description: It’s everywhere, and we’re fighting against the wrong one.
item.dc:creator: ATOSSA ARAXIA ABRAHAMIAN

item.title: ‘This Is Our Land’
item.media:description: A digger with bags of cobalt in Kolwezi, Democratic Republic of Congo. Congo abounds in cobalt, crucial for electronic devices.
item.media:credit: Sebastian Meyer/Corbis News, via Getty Images
item.description: Mineral riches should make Congo prosperous. Instead, they fuel corruption, which has kept the people poor and compromised elections.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. KAVANAGH

item.title: God Bless America, and Her Lawyers
item.media:description: Volunteer immigration lawyers at Kennedy Airport in January 2017, working on behalf of passengers denied entry after President Trump barred immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: ‘It’s like someone is running around sticking their finger in people’s eyes and I’m an eye doctor.’
item.dc:creator: MAEVE HIGGINS

item.title: ‘Ellie’ Was a Rising Star in the Gaming World. Or Was She?
item.description: The strange saga of a fake female gamer and her encounter with the misogynistic world of e-sports.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN CONDIS

item.title: Steve Martin Appears as Roger Stone on ‘Saturday Night Live’
item.description: Wearing a pinstripe suit and projecting his voice at maximum volume, Martin played Stone, the longtime Trump adviser who was arrested on Friday.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: Trump National Golf Club in N.Y. Fires Undocumented Workers, Lawyer Says
item.media:description: About a dozen workers at the Trump National Golf Club in Westchester, N.Y., were fired this month because they were in the country illegally, according to their lawyer.
item.description: About a dozen employees — housekeepers, landscapers and a head chef — were fired this month because they were in the country illegally, according to their lawyer.
item.dc:creator: MIHIR ZAVERI and ANNIE CORREAL

item.title: With Hundreds Missing Following Burst Brazil Dam, a Frantic Search for Survivors
item.media:description: Rescuers searching for victims after the collapse of a dam in southeastern Brazil on Friday. They have saved 189, but hundreds remain missing.
item.description: At least 34 people have been killed, but officials feared that many more will be found as rescue teams dig through feet of mud.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: 3 Men Sentenced in Plot to Bomb Somali Immigrants in Kansas
item.media:description: A makeshift mosque inside an apartment complex in Garden City, Kan., that three men were convicted of plotting to bomb.
item.description: The men were each sentenced to at least 25 years in prison after they were convicted of planning to blow up an apartment complex.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Prince Philip Says He’s ‘Deeply Sorry’ About Car Crash
item.media:description: Prince Philip at Windsor Castle last year. The recent car crash involving the prince, who is 97, prompted a debate on older drivers in Britain.
item.description: The 97-year-old Duke of Edinburgh apologized in a letter to a woman who sustained a broken wrist in the accident, British news outlets reported.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Fatima Ali, Fan Favorite on ‘Top Chef,’ Dies of Cancer at 29
item.media:description: Fatima Ali died on Friday from Ewing’s sarcoma, a rare form of cancer. She was the first Pakistani woman to win “Chopped” and also appeared on “Top Chef.”
item.description: Ms. Ali publicly battled a rare form of cancer for a year while she sought to fulfill her final wish of eating at the best restaurants in the world.
item.dc:creator: JEFFERY C. MAYS

item.title: Karachi Seeks to Remake Itself, With Bulldozers Leading the Way
item.media:description: Empress Market in Karachi, Pakistan, where shops were bulldozed in November as part of a government campaign against unofficial construction.
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.description: A government campaign against unofficial construction in Pakistan’s largest city is leaving hundreds of hawkers without a livelihood, but the Empress Market walls are visible from the sidewalk.
item.dc:creator: MEHER AHMAD

item.title: Jared Kushner, a Confident Negotiator, Finds Immigration Deal to Be Elusive
item.media:description: Jared Kushner agreed to take the lead when President Trump, his father-in-law, asked him to find a way to end the monthlong stalemate over funding for a southern border wall.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: It has been challenging for Mr. Kushner to negotiate a broad immigration deal that would satisfy a president committed to a border wall and Democrats who have repeatedly cast it as immoral.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE KARNI and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: On the Way to Auschwitz, I Found ‘Heil Hitler’ Signs For Sale
item.description: On a Holocaust education trip in Poland, a writer discovers Nazi memorabilia at a flea market, in apparent violation of the law. But nothing is quite that simple.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA S. LEVINE

item.title: Speaking Black Dialect in Courtrooms Can Have Striking Consequences
item.media:description: A person walks past the federal courthouse in Philadelphia. A study found court reporters in the city regularly made errors in transcribing sentences that were spoken in black dialect.
item.description: A soon-to-be published study found court reporters in Philadelphia regularly made errors when transcribing sentences spoken in a dialect linguists term African-American English.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ELIGON

item.title: How to Use ‘Do Not Disturb’ on Your Phone (While Still Letting Important Calls Through)
item.description: The bliss of turning off all notifications on your phone doesn’t have to come with the anxiety of potentially missing an important call or text. Here’s how you can have it all.
item.dc:creator: WHITSON GORDON

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: Vampire Weekend’s Plucky Return, and 15 More New Songs
item.media:description: After a six-year gap, Vampire Weekend has returned.
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Hear tracks by Phoebe Bridgers and Conor Oberst, Dua Lipa, J. Cole and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: Why People Ghost — and How to Get Over It
item.description: Time to go ghostbusting.
item.dc:creator: ADAM POPESCU

item.title: Crowdwise: How to Handle the Dreaded ‘Reply All Moment’
item.description: You know that sinking feeling when you accidentally click "Reply All" instead of "Reply?" It's awful. Here's how to handle it, and make sure it never happens again.
item.dc:creator: DAVID POGUE

item.title: Vows: Cemetery Was the Right Vibe for a Glamour Goth Wedding
item.media:description: Ally Jane Grossan and Nabil Ayers met at a wedding. They bonded over a shared love of music.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Lippman for The New York Times
item.description: Ally Grossan, a music aficionado, and the rock musician Nabil Ayers, who has jazz in his blood, aren’t the “wedding factory” types.
item.dc:creator: MOLLY CREEDEN

item.title: Sunday Routine: How Madison McFerrin, Singer, Spends Her Sundays
item.media:description: Madison McFerrin, at home with her boyfriend and manager, Ned Levy.
item.media:credit: Melissa Bunni Elian for The New York Times
item.description: She comes from music royalty, but that doesn’t stop her from committing to her craft in the afternoons. She also works in time for cooking and Netflix.
item.dc:creator: TAMMY La GORCE

item.title: Encounters: Haley Joel Osment Plays Pool at His Favorite N.Y.U. Hangout
item.media:description: Haley Joel Osment at Fat Cat in Greenwich Village.
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
item.description: The former child actor stars in the new season of “Future Man.”
item.dc:creator: ALEXIS SOLOSKI

item.title: Five Weeknight Dishes: This Soup Deserves an Award
item.media:description: An easy weeknight dinner: chicken breast cooked with lemons and herbs.
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews. Prop Stylist: Paige Hicks.
item.description: In the category of converting people into lentil-soup lovers, this superb recipe takes highest honors.
item.dc:creator: EMILY WEINSTEIN

item.title: At War: The Day They Came to Tell Me My Husband Died
item.description: Grieving people remember compassion, like the compassion I received from the sheriff’s deputies who stayed by my side until I was no longer alone.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA THOMAS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘This Could Be the End’ for NASA’s Mars Opportunity Rover
item.media:description: An artist's rendering of NASA's Opportunity rover on the surface of Mars.
item.description: The agency has received only silence from the intrepid explorer since contact was lost during a global dust storm on the red planet last June.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: ‘Hamlet’ in Virtual Reality Casts the Viewer in the Play
item.media:description: Steven Maler directed “Hamlet 360” and is the founding artistic director of Commonwealth Shakespeare Company. “This is a way to put into the classroom an extraordinary experience of this play,” he said.
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.description: A joint production by a Boston theater company and Google hopes to bring high-quality Shakespeare to wider audiences, and new audiences into theaters.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

item.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
item.media:description: Sarah Quismondo and Alberto Ayala at an Our CarShare location in Sacramento.
item.media:credit: Bradley Berman for The New York Times
item.description: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: BRADLEY BERMAN

item.title: A Race Against Space
item.media:credit: Beatrice de Gea for The New York Times
item.description: One of the tenets of neurosurgery is that the cranium, the bone that encases the brain, can fit only so much.
item.dc:creator: ABDUL-KAREEM AHMED, M.D.
